etymologies: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘formation of the mind, teaching’), via Old French from Latin informatio(n-), from the verb informare (see inform)

definitions: facts provided or learned about something or someone
a formal criminal charge lodged with a court or magistrate by a prosecutor without the aid of a grand jury

examples.text: the tenant may lay an information against his landlord

definitions: what is conveyed or represented by a particular arrangement or sequence of things
shortDefinitions: what is conveyed by particular arrangement of things

definitions: data as processed, stored, or transmitted by a computer.
shortDefinitions: data as processed, stored, or transmitted by computer

definitions: (in information theory) a mathematical quantity expressing the probability of occurrence of a particular sequence of symbols, impulses, etc., as contrasted with that of alternative sequences.
shortDefinitions: quantity expressing probability of occurrence of particular sequence as against alternative
